http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/guest-blog/2011/07/28/maybe-black-holes-dont-really-exist/
Discuss.

item.description:

protip: Never listen to Fails.

No, we should not listen to him.

So we should listen to him?

[/quote]
So, we should stay off topic?[/quote]
Nope, you should get back on topic or you won’t be posting in any topics anytime soon.

item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

We observe whats around a black hole as we cannot see the black hole itself, their are many reasons to not claim it is one but most probably it is one.

Read full topic

item.title: Black Holes
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

RandQm:

The pictures you can find are “possible black holes” as nasa says themselves. There is never an actual black hole found.

nasa has that disclaimer because in case you haven’t noticed, scientists are the last type of people who claim something with absolute certainty, you’ll also notice the disclaimer on nebulae and galaxies

we can observe black holes in the sense we observe something that matches what we think black holes to be, if you observe what you think is a galaxy 9 times out of 10, it probably isn’t a galaxy but if multiple studies also show similar results then what you are looking at would be “a possible galaxy”

we can also observe the effect black holes have, such as observing the effect of stars and gasses around the centre of our galaxy for 16 years and then finding out from the data how big it may be and how far it is, we obviously can’t observe the black hole but we can observe the orbits of the stars around it and compare it to what we know about how objects orbit

here’s a video demonstrating the orbits:


skip to about 1:00 if you’re impatient

Read full topic

item.title: Black Holes
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

RandQm:

there isn’t actual proof that it does.

There hasn’t ever been actual proof, they’re all theoretical probabilities. However, just because there isn’t proof doesn’t mean you can’t put belief in a theory.

Read full topic

item.title: Black Holes
item.dc:creator: @RandQm RandQm
item.description:
@RandQm wrote:

Black holes seem to be an accepted thing among people, but recently I’ve read that there isn’t actual proof that it does.
The pictures you can find are “possible black holes” as nasa says themselves. There is never an actual black hole found.
Also what is a black hole exactly? There are different theories about it so when can we really say something is a black hole.

Read full topic

item.title: Black Holes
item.dc:creator: @rip4d rip4d
item.description:
@rip4d wrote:

Black holes do exist,but they aren’t exactly holes as much as they are tiny “magnets” that pull literally everything in that’s near them. You can’t go through one, only around. Its a solid mass, trying to dive through it is like smashing your head into the wall of a bomb shelter in hopes of making it through.

Read full topic

I believe they do exist, however I wouldn’t be surprised if what we think black holes are is wrong. I think it would be possible to one day enter one and come back to explain what is happening although current science says it is not possible.
But yet again the human race would probably die out before we got to that level of technology…

item.title: Black Holes
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

Of course black holes exist, there are contrasting theories on event horizons but black holes themselves exist. There’s two popular beliefs on black holes, that they infact own event horizons and that they don’t. Black holes with no event horizons come about if you look at them by the functional Schrodinger equation (the mathematical way) you’d find that the black hole as it’s forming it collapses in on itself. The scientists studying this way find that the gravity of the collapsing mass starts disturbing the quantum vacuum. This generates whats called pre-hawking radiation. This radiation loss causes the mass of the object to be greatly reduced and means it can never achieve the correct density to form an event horizon.

I believe that black holes exist, but do infact have event horizons and the theory above isn’t true. Of course, we won’t know for quite some time yet.

Read full topic

San Antonio Express-News – 29 Nov 12

UT astronomers find massive black hole at heart of a nearby galaxy

According to observations made at the McDonald Observatory with the University of Texas at Austin's Hobby-Eberly Telescope, the giant black hole is 11 times wider than Neptune's orbit around the sun. “We don't understand how to make such a massive...
